unnormalised: One of the biggest buzzwords right now is AI, or Artificial Intelligence. It's not just about robots taking over the world (though, who knows, maybe that's happening!). We're talking massive data sets, complex algorithms, and the potential to revolutionize industries. The investment in AI is projected to reach $500 billion USD by 2027 – pretty impressive, right?

normalised: Then there's cybersecurity, which is becoming increasingly critical. With more and more of our lives moving online, protecting our data from cyberattacks is paramount. Think about it – your Aadhaar number, your bank details, your embarrassing childhood photos – all vulnerable to hackers! Companies are investing heavily in cybersecurity measures, and the demand for skilled professionals in this field is booming. Learning ethical hacking could get you a job with a salary starting at rupee five lakhs p.a.

unnormalised: Cloud computing is another game-changer. Instead of storing data on physical servers, businesses are increasingly relying on cloud-based solutions. This offers greater flexibility, scalability, and cost-effectiveness. Amazon Web Services (AWS), Microsoft Azure, and Google Cloud Platform (GCP) are the big players in this space, and they're constantly innovating and expanding their services. Many smaller businesses are adopting a cloud-first strategy, skipping the traditional server room altogether. This allows them to focus on their core business while leaving the IT infrastructure to the experts.

This offers greater flexibility, scalability, and cost-effectiveness. Amazon Web Services (A-W-S), Microsoft Azure, and Google Cloud Platform (G-C-P) are the big players in this space, and they're constantly innovating and expanding their services. Many smaller businesses are adopting a cloud-first strategy, skipping the traditional server room altogether. This allows them to focus on their core business while leaving the I-T infrastructure to the experts.

unnormalised: And let's not forget about the Internet of Things (IoT). From smart homes to connected cars, IoT devices are becoming increasingly prevalent. These devices collect and transmit data, enabling us to automate tasks, improve efficiency, and gain valuable insights. However, IoT also raises concerns about privacy and security, as these devices can be vulnerable to hacking. Think about your smart fridge reporting your eating habits to advertisers – creepy, right?
